Q-Dir makes your files and folders easy to manage. Quick and easy access, with an amazing technique based on a quadruple view.

You donâ€™t have to give up the usual Drag and Drop, all Views, and other features of your system.
Year! Q-Dir gives you other nice features, which will make you happy.
Many hand movements and time can be saved!

Q-Dir does not have to be installed and can be easily launched from the desktop.
Rename Q-Dir_Installer.exe to Q-Dir.exe and DONE!!!.
Itâ€™s a famous little utility for Windows OS and itâ€™s also a friend of USB sticks ^_^.
WARNING: Once Q-Dir, always Q-Dir ;)!

ShortcutFunction
[CTRL+X]Cut
[CTRL+C]Copy
[CTRL+V]To take
[CTRL+A]Select all.
[CTRL+T]New tab
[CTRL+W]Close the last tab.
[CTRL+SHIFT+T]New tab from the selected folder.
[CTRL+SHIFT+A]reverse selection
[CTRL+TAB]Next tab
[CTRL+SHIFT+TAB]Previous tab
[CTRL+E]toggle tree
[CTRL+Z]Undo
[CTRL+Q]Links-Quick Menu

[CTRL+S]Start of the program.

[CTRL+Num+]Autosize columns.
..
[CTRL+ALT+(Control-Key)]Quick control change
..
[UP]Eliminate
[RECOIL]Go the folder one level up
..
[F2]Rename/Rename only
[F3]Search for a file or folder

..

[ALT+SHIFT+BACKSET]Keep it up
..

FavoritesQuick access to the most used folders.
Drag and DropMove files by dragging them in views-Q and other programs like MS Explorer.

columnsAll columns support and retain this feature.

Tree ViewSimple and quadruple.

PortableSince version 2.77 Q-Dir is portable.

6. Rä¸­çš„extdata

Extdata is a convention used by some R packages to store external data files, such as data files used for examples in the package documentation or vignettes. It is not a formally defined term, but a subdirectory of the inst directory that gets copied to the installation directory of the package. To access the files in the extdata directory, you can use the system.file function with the package name and the file name as argumentsÂ¹Â³â´. For example:

fpath <- system.file(â€œextdataâ€, â€œmy_raw_data.csvâ€, package=â€my_packageâ€)

This will give you the absolute path to the file on your hard drive. You can then use read.csv or other functions to read the file.

10. foo, bar and spam

In the world of computer programming, â€œfooâ€ and â€œbarâ€ are commonly used as generic examples of the names of files, users, programs, classes, hosts, etc. Thus, you will frequently encounter them in manual (man) pages, syntax descriptions, and other computer documentation.

What do foo and bar mean
language agnostic - What does â€˜fooâ€™ really mean - Stack Overflow
Metasyntactic variable - Wikipedia
2023-0805

Genomic Feature

This is a generic and general term to describe any genomic region with some annotated function. E.g. a gene, CDS, mRNA, rRNA, tRNA, repeat sequence, inverted repeat, miRNA, siRNA, origin of replication. A given genomic feature may be comprised of multiple specific genomic locations that together form the genomic feature. For example, a protein coding gene (CDS) is encoded by a gene that has multiple exons. Each exon is spliced together to form a mature mRNA. The CDS feature itself is therefore comprised of multiple genomic locations that neighbor one another.

æ¥æº:
Genomic Feature - CoGepedia
2023-0808

Functional annotation

Functional annotation is the process of attaching biological information to sequences of genes or proteins. The basic level of annotation is using sequence alignment tool BLAST for finding similarities, and then annotating genes or proteins based on that. Nevertheless, nowadays more and more additional information of biological functions is added to the annotation system. The additional information allows hand-operated annotation to distinguish genes or proteins that have the same annotation. With many genomes sequenced, computational annotation approaches to characterize genes and proteins from their sequence are increasingly important.
